subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range of Linear Transformations
contentHtml: Linear transformations are a fundamental concept in linear algebra.

problem.statementHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^3 defined by

  • T([x, y]) = [x, y, x + y]
problem.solutionHtml:
To find the kernel, we need to solve T(x) = [0, 0, 0].

  1. Let T([x, y]) = [0, 0, 0]. Then x + y = 0.
  2. This is a linear equation in two variables. The solution set is the line y = -x.
  3. The kernel is spanned by this line.

workedExample.problemHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^3 defined by

  • T([x, y]) = [x, y, x + y]

steps.explanation: The kernel is the set of all vectors that are mapped to zero.
This gives us a linear equation in two variables.
The solution set is the line y = -x.
To find the range, we need to find all possible outputs of T.

intuition: The kernel and range of a linear transformation provide important insights into its behavior.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range of Linear Transformations
contentHtml:
In linear algebra, we often encounter linear transformations between vector spaces.

Given a transformation T: V → W, our goal is to understand its kernel (null space) and range (image).
name: Linear Transformation" },
statementHtml:
Consider the linear transformation T: ℝ² → ℝ³ defined by

\[\begin{bmatrix}T_1\\T_2\\T_3\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix}\]. Find the kernel and range of T.

",
hints: Hint: Use the transformation matrix to find the null space
solutionHtml:
Step 1: Compute the null space

\[\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} \in \ker T \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}\]

Step 2: Find the null space

\[\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} \in \ker T \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad x + y = 0\]

Step 3: Compute the range

\[T(\mathbf{v}) = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}x + y \\ x + y \\ (x+y) + y\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}2(x+y) \\ 2(x+y) \\ 3(x+y)\end{bmatrix}\]

Step 4: Find the range

\[T(\mathbf{v}) = \begin{bmatrix}2x \\ 2x \\ 3x\end{bmatrix}, x \in ℝ\]

",
answerShort: The kernel is the set of vectors satisfying \(x + y = 0\), and the range is the set of vectors of the form \(\begin{bmatrix}2x \\ 2x \\ 3x\end{bmatrix}\)" },

",
explanation: We simplify the expression for the transformation and find that it is a linear combination of the standard basis vectors." } ],
finalAnswer: The kernel is the set of vectors satisfying \(x + y = 0\), and the range is the set of vectors of the form \(\begin{bmatrix}2x \\ 2x \\ 3x\end{bmatrix}\)" },
intuition: Understanding the kernel and range of a linear transformation is crucial in many applications, including machine learning where it helps to identify the underlying structure of data.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range: Understanding Linear Transformations
contentHtml: In linear algebra, a linear transformation is a function that preserves vector addition and scalar multiplication.

problem.statementHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: \mathbb{R}^2 → \mathbb{R}^3 defined by:

  • A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{bmatrix}
hints: Hint: Find the null space and column space of A
problem.solutionHtml:
Step 1: Compute the determinant of A.

  • \[\det(A) = (1)(1) - (0)(0) = 1\]

Why? We compute the determinant to find the volume scaling factor for the transformation.
problem.answerShort: The kernel is span{<math>(1, 0)</math>} and the range is \mathbb{R}^3

steps.explanation: We compute the determinant to find the volume scaling factor for the transformation.

steps.description: Find the null space of A
steps.explanation: The null space contains all vectors that are mapped to zero.

steps.description: Find the column space of A
steps.explanation: The column space contains all linear combinations of the columns of A.

steps.description: Determine if T is injective or surjective
steps.mathHtml: \[T\text{ is not injective since } (1, 0) \mapsto (1, 0), but it is surjective since the range is \mathbb{R}^3\]
steps.explanation: We check if T is one-to-one and onto.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The kernel is span{<math>(1, 0)</math>} and the range is \mathbb{R}^3

intuition: Understanding the kernel and range of a linear transformation provides insight into its behavior and properties.
visualDescription: A diagram showing the null space and column space of A
commonMistakes: Not recognizing that T is not injective
